results.title: The Fury
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma, Frank Yablans and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Brian De Palma’s “The Fury” is a schizophrenic genre fusion of horror, action, political intrigue and supernatural thriller. De Palma revisits the realm of telekinesis which he first explored in Carrie (1976), giving it a kinetic spin this time around. Kirk Douglas plays Peter Sanza, a government agent who’s psychic son Robin (Andrew Stevens) is kidnapped while they are on holiday in the middle east. Fearing for his own life Peter goes into hiding and enlists the help of another Psychic (William Finley) to help him track down his son. Meanwhile Chicago teenager Gillian (Amy Irving) enrols into the Paragon Institute for Psychic research as she struggles to control her unruly telekinetic powers. However Gillian soon finds herself in danger as she begins to uncover a government plot involving her and Peter’s son Robin. Cast includes: John Cassavetes, Carrie Snodgress, Charles Durning, Fiona Lewis.

results.title: Guarding Tess
results.creator_credit: Hugh Wilson, Nancy Graham Tanen, Ned Tanen, Channel and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Tess Carlisle (Shirley MacLaine) is the widow of a former president of the United States who has become a national treasure. Doug Chesnic (Nicolas Cage) is the secret security agent that is hired to ensure that she stays safe and out of trouble. Doug, accustomed to assignments that involve danger and excitement, dreads his mundane task and he finds Tess patronising, eccentric, rude, demanding and acerbic. Typically within the odd-couple formula, these two adversaries have to reach a truce, which for Doug means trying to maintain his exacting standards despite the unpredictable nature of Tess’ whims. An attempt on Tess’ life and a mystery illness provide narrative developments, but it is mostly the shenanigans and intricacies of the secret service operatives that keep the film interesting. “Guarding Tess” drifts toward melodrama and tends to exude a cloying sentimentality, but it also contains a certain charm due to the performances of Cage and MacLaine. Directed by Hugh Wilson (The First wives club, Dudley do right).

results.title: Peggy Sue got married
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Paul R. Gurian, Zoetrope Studios, Rastar Films and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Disillusioned with her life and the disintegration of her marriage to her childhood sweetheart (Nicolas Cage), former prom queen Peggy Sue (Kathleen Turner) reluctantly attends her 25 year high school reunion. Confronted by her past, she begins to regret her life choices and missed opportunities. Emotionally overwhelmed, she collapses during the reunion and awakens as herself 25 years earlier. Armed with experience and a second chance, she sets out, determined not repeat the same mistakes. A comedy fantasy film also starring Joan Allen, Helen Hunt, Jim Carrey, Maureen O’Sullivan, Leon Ames, John Carradine. Script, Jerry Leichtling and Arlene Sarner. Music, John Barry. Editing, Barry Malkin. Cinematography, Jordan Cronenweth.

results.title: The Tango lesson [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sally Potter, Christopher Sheppard, Neue Deutsche Filmgesellschaft, PIE and OKCK Films
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Sally Potter returns to her dancing roots (‘The Golddiggers’ was her first musical) by casting herself as a film director suffering from writer’s block who sets out to take tango lessons from a Paris-based teacher (Pablo Veron, playing himself). Veron has always dreamed of being in a movie and Sally is starting to dream of a film about tango. Potter’s film is divided into twelve lessons during which the two protagonists learn about each other, fight over who is leading who, start a love story, and eventually end up in Buenos Aires to learn from the tango masters. The film is shot mostly in black and white, except for some dream sequences in which Sally fantasizes about an ill-fated film project. Veron performs many modern dance numbers, including tap and ballroom dancing, as part of his tango repertoire.

results.title: Memento [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Nolan, Jennifer Todd, Suzanne Todd and Newmarket Films
results.brief_description: The second feature by Christopher Nolan accomplishes what seems impossible: to tell a movie backwards. Leonard (Guy Pearce) is a former Insurance Investigator whose successful career was cut short by a violent incident which deprived him of his ability to make new memories, transforming his life into an epic quest for vengeance. But his mental condition makes him vulnerable to those who would take advantage, and the lengths to which he’ll go to give his life some logic prove frightening. A disorienting but ultimately ingenious thriller. Cast also includes Joe Pantoliano and Carrie-Anne Moss.

results.title: Legally blonde
results.creator_credit: Robert Luketic, Ric Kidney, Marc Platt and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A lively comedy by Australian filmmaker, and Swinburne graduate, Robert Luketic. Reese Witherspoon stars as fashion merchandising graduate, Elle Woods, eagerly anticipating a marriage proposal from her politically ambitious boyfriend, Warner Huntington III (Matthew Davis). When he dumps her to search for a woman more suited to the role of senator’s wife, Elle sets out to win him back. Determined to improve her chances by becoming his intellectual equal, she enrols into Harvard Law School after her vibrant application impresses the admissions board. Her Southern Californian Bimbo appearance, bubbly personality and casual approach to study set her apart from the other Ivy League students. Initially an outcast, Elle’s blonde ambition eventually secures her reputation as a force to be reckoned with, propelling her to the top of her class. Cast also includes: Luke Wilson, Selma Blair and Raquel Welch. Screenplay by Karen McCullah Lutz and Kirsten Smith, based on the book by Amanda Brown. Cinematography, Anthony B. Richmond.

results.title: Interrogation = Przesluchanie [NTSC] (D)
results.creator_credit: Ryszard Bugajski, Tadeusz Drewno and Film Polski
results.brief_description: This powerful Polish drama about the methodical, psychological brutalization of a woman prisoner in totalitarian 1950s Warsaw was originally banned on its release in 1982 by the Polish government (then under martial law) who declared it to be inflammatory and dangerous. Director Ryszard Bugajski escaped to Canada with a smuggled copy of the film enabling him to show it at various film festivals until 1990 when the Cannes Film Festival awarded its Best Actress Award to Krystyna Janda for her riveting performance in the leading role of Tonia Dziwisz. Tonia is married, a cabaret singer out to enjoy life, rather naive and A-political. After a drunken one night stand with a military officer Tonia awakens the morning after to find herself in a prison cell with several other women prisoners, and with no knowledge as to how and why she is there. The story takes a chilling turn and we are witness to some of the most horrifying abuse and torture, relentless in its intensity and disturbing in its graphically realistic images. The vicious interrogations which Tonia is continually subjected to only increase her inner strength to survive, to maintain her dignity and her sanity and to never give up. As harrowing and confronting as it may be, this film is compulsory viewing, brilliant in its directing and its cast with Janusz Gajos and Adam Ferency in the roles of the interrogators - Gajos as the meticulous but sadistically cruel Citizen Major and Ferency as the second but more sympathetic interrogator, Morawsky. “Interrogation” will stay with you long after you have seen it. Cast also includes Agnieszke Holland and Anna Romantowska. WARNING: CONTAINS MANY DISTURBING IMAGES, VIOLENCE AND NUDITY.

results.title: That Hamilton woman
results.creator_credit: Alexander Korda and Alexander Korda Films
results.brief_description: That Hamilton woman opens in France, where a destitute and alcoholic woman is arrested for stealing. The woman in question is Lady Emma Hamilton (Vivien Leigh), a once famed beauty. In jail, Emma tells her story to a cellmate, casting back to a time when she was young and lovely. An English woman born to a low class, with a past riddled with infamy, Emma had managed to rise above her station. In Naples Emma is a guest of Sir William Hamilton, a British ambassador, who offers her a financially secure but loveless marriage, to which she agrees. Emma is received at court and revels in the social status of being Lady Hamilton. One day her world is upended with the arrival of Lord Nelson (Laurence Olivier), a British naval hero. Over the course of several years, Emma and Nelson are shown to have a growing affection for one another which blossoms into love. Both are in loveless marriages but divorce is impossible and society views their union with scorn. Leigh excels as Hamilton, a brave woman, beaten by societal mores of the day. The film caused a scandal in America for its depiction of adultery, and dialogue was added to portray the lovers as suffering for their indiscretions.

results.title: The Private life of Henry VIII = The Private life of Henry Eighth
results.creator_credit: Alexander Korda, Ludovico Toeplitz and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: Charles Laughton won an Academy Award for his portrayal of Henry VIII in this film directed and co-produced by Alexander Korda. As the title suggests, the narrative plots the private life of Henry VIII - six marriages and numerous affairs for a hedonistic creature given to excess in all areas of life. Laughton plays Henry as an exuberant, gargantuan man with a lusty libido and appetite but little regard for the lives of others. The film is largely comedic in tone but does address some of Henry’s political struggles and ambitions for England. Period detail and lavish costumes set the 16th century scene, even if the dialogue has a more modern tone. Cast includes: Merle Oberon, Wendy Barrie, Elsa Lanchester, Binnie Barnes, Robert Donnat and Everly Gregg. Despite not winning the Academy Award for Best Picture, the success of “The Private life of Henry VIII” put British cinema on the map, which was from then on regarded as a real threat to Hollywood domination of the market.
